results.title: Twin [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Lee and James Ruse Agricultural High
results.brief_description:
‘Twin’ is a videogame that highlights the importance of self-respect. It is based upon the Hero’s search for those who took away his ‘colour’. As his colour has been taken away, he has been reduced to his black and white form; his own being is split into two. The Hero realises his colour was in fact not stolen and by being able to overcome the puzzles and challenges brought by each level, the Hero begins to respect himself and is ultimately able to retrieve his ‘colours.’

A 2D problem solving/puzzle showing respect starts with self. This trailer illustrates how the game is played.
Under the category ‘Secondary Games’, James Ruse Agricultural High School’s Nicholas Lee, Year 12, was the Screen It 2011 winner.

results.title: The Respect Quest [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Christopher Halse, Liam Blake and Tea Tree Gully Primary School
results.brief_description:
Time Monsters are spreading disrespect in the community and causing havoc. Help local villagers and elders restore respect by defeating the Time Monsters with a magic boomerang. Jump on platforms, collect coins and explore through the mountains of time. Money gained on the quest will help rebuild the villages after respect is restored.

This trailer illustrates how the game is played.
Under the category ‘Primary Games’, Tea Tree Gully Primary School’s Liam Blake and Christopher Halse, Grade 5, were the Screen It 2011 winners.

results.title: The Locket
results.brief_description:
It would be easy to discard a worthless, old locket found on the beach but, out of respect for a serviceman in a black and white photo, an old man embarks on a journey to return the memento to its original owner. He travels a long way from his lonely, daily routine and unearths respect for himself and a fallen solider. ‘The Locket’ is a snapshot of a life we don’t know we’re in until something – or someone – snaps you out of it.
Cast Includes: John Murphy, Iris Whitakker, David Jellie, Victoria Upward, Gomer Jones and Nadine Crichton.
Under the category ‘Secondary Live Action’, this independent entry by Blake Borcich, Year 10, was the Screen It 2011 winner.

results.title: Caught In The Crowd
results.creator_credit: India Thompson and Norwood Primary School
results.brief_description:
Piper and Nick were best friends from a young age but as they grew up, Piper became one of the most popular girls in the school and studious Nick fell into the nerdy group. School bullies harass Nick while Piper looks on concerned. She is torn when Nick calls to her for help. Will Piper risk her popularity to respect their life-long friendship, or will she be caught in the crowd?
Written and directed by India Thompson with Film Support by Michael Hilbert and Sue Chapple. Cast includes: Piper Adams, Nicholas House, Emma Johnstone and Cameron Wicks.
Under the category ‘Primary Live Action’, Norwood Primary School’s 5/6 Chapple/Dennis class were the Screen It 2011 winners.

results.title: Buzz Off
results.brief_description:
This clay-animated story is about respect for others who are different or have different cultures. Overcome by Bees, The Jewel Beetles must flee their home to find a safe place to live. Forced to brave a treacherous river and evade hungry predators, the Jewel Beetles reach the safety of Grasshopper Land. They overhear a debate between two grasshoppers. One grasshopper believes that beetles would bring new perspectives and cultures to Grasshopper Land, while the other grasshopper, fearing change, thinks the beetles don’t belong. Intolerance or acceptance will determine the Jewel Beetles’ fate.
Under the category ‘Primary Animation’, Yarraville West Primary School’s 5/6 Film Team were the Screen It 2011 winners.

results.title: Out of Sight Out of Mind [Part 1]
results.creator_credit: David Goldie and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Part One (only) of the four-part series ‘Out of Sight, Out of Mind’.

This documentary, made for the ABC in 1987, helped to raise awareness about a much neglected section of our society. It provided extensive insight into the prison system, interviewing prisoners, prison officers and administrators.

The full work has four parts titled ‘Locked Up’, ‘Surviving in the Nick’, ‘The Keepers and the Kept’, and ‘The Cycle of Crime’. This program pulls no punches, describes the conditions of various correctional institutions around Australia and also offers some suggestions for improvements.

results.title: Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences interviews
results.creator_credit: Jason White, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences’ is the first in the ‘New Horizons’ series of ACMI commissions. Gladwell uses filmic devices such as slow-motion and long pans to capture both tightly choreographed and improvised performances by breakdancers, skateboarders and BMX bike riders in a combination of rural and city settings. The resulting works, which he describes as “performative landscapes” are both rhythmic and poetic - distorting speed, gravity, space and time; exploring visual and spatial paradoxes. He discusses his art practice and his collaboration with other performers and artists for this exhibition. Other interviews include; Sarah Tutton (ACMI curator), Josh Raymond (Gladwell producer) Vivienne Wong (Australian Ballet) and Lamaroc (street dancer).

results.title: Back to the brickworks
results.brief_description: In the 1800s, brickmaking was one of the largest manufacturing industries in Australia. Hoffman’s Brickworks in Brunswick, Victoria, was a leader of this industry, running for 133 years and fostering a strong union. Indeed Hoffman’s was the birthplace of the Brickmaker’s Union in Victoria. In this film, director Grant Hobson covers the final week of operation of this historic site, in December 1993. He interviews the union representatives and the close family of workers, some of whom he is able to reunite in May 2010 on the site. It is a nostalgic reflection on the heyday and demise of brickmaking in Victoria, as well as capturing the colourful personalities that illustrate the post-war migrant experience in relation to work and settling in Melbourne.

production_dates.notes: Footage filmed in December 16, 1993 and May 23, 2010

results.title: Arthur and Corinne Cantrill interview
results.brief_description:
Arthur and Corinne Cantrill have been making films together since 1960. Initially focusing on documentaries about art they moved on to experimental film in 1969. From 1971 to 2000 they edited and published Cantrills Filmnotes, a journal on film and video art. Their film work and publishing are well-known internationally and have been represented in several film collections.

In this interview with Fiona Trigg, ACMI Exhibitions Assistant Curator, Arthur and Corinne talk about their early days of expanded cinema and their technical and creative processes.

results.title: Disney Masterclass with Roy Conli and Glen Keane
results.brief_description:
Disney Animator Glen Keane and Producer Roy Conli presented a special Masterclass sharing their behind-the-scenes insights and love of the animation process.
Glen Keane has been with the Walt Disney Studios for over 25 years and is best known for his character animations for feature films such as ‘The Little Mermaid’, ‘Aladdin’, ‘Beauty and the Beast’, ‘Tarzan’, and ‘Tangled’. He reflects on the inspirations for some of his characters and expressing yourself through drawing.
Roy Conli is the producer of the Disney feature animated film, ‘Tangled’, based on the story of Rapunzel. He explains the role of the producer and the line between creating a safe and fertile environment for artists and getting a film made on time and within budget.
